title: Use descriptive topic names
description: Topic names should clearly describe what the topic does. Use verb-noun format like Handle-PaymentInquiry.
rationale: Descriptive names make agents easier to maintain. Other makers can understand the structure at a glance.
example_good: Handle-PaymentInquiry, Greet-NewUser, Escalate-ToHuman
example_bad: Topic1, NewTopic, HandleIt

title: Always handle the else branch in conditions
description: Every condition node should have both branches defined. Never leave an else branch empty.
rationale: Undefined branches cause unexpected behavior or leave users without a response.
example_good: If condition met → response A. Else → response B or redirect.
example_bad: If condition met → response A. Else → (nothing)

title: Use variables for repeated values
description: Store values used multiple times in variables: API endpoints, common messages, config values.
rationale: Change a value once instead of hunting through multiple topics.
example_good: Set Topic.ApiEndpoint once, use it everywhere
example_bad: Hardcode the same URL in every HTTP node

title: Validate user input before processing
description: Always validate user input from entities and questions before using in API calls or logic.
rationale: Invalid input causes API errors, unexpected behavior, or security issues.
example_good: Check if email entity is valid format before API request
example_bad: Pass user input directly to API without checking

title: Use system topics for global behavior
description: Customize system topics (Greeting, Fallback, Escalate) for consistent behavior instead of duplicating logic.
rationale: System topics trigger automatically. Customizing them ensures consistent handling.
example_good: Edit system Fallback topic to log and offer escalation
example_bad: Add fallback handling to every individual topic

title: Test with multiple conversation paths
description: Test edge cases, invalid inputs, unexpected responses, and conversation abandonment.
rationale: Real users don't follow scripts. Test multiple paths for real-world scenarios.
example_good: Test: valid input, invalid input, user says never mind, unrelated question mid-flow
example_bad: Only test the exact flow you designed

title: Set appropriate scope for variables
description: Use Topic variables for values needed within a topic. Use Global only when values must persist across topics.
rationale: Proper scoping prevents conflicts and makes debugging easier.
example_good: Topic.UserEmail for this topic. Global.UserLanguage for everywhere.
example_bad: Using Global variables for everything

title: Use generative answers for knowledge-based questions
description: For questions answered from knowledge sources, use generative answers instead of hard-coding.
rationale: Generative answers stay up-to-date as knowledge changes. Hard-coded needs manual updates.
example_good: Add SharePoint as knowledge, let AI answer policy questions
example_bad: Create a topic with hard-coded vacation policy text

title: Handle HTTP errors gracefully
description: Always check HTTP response status codes and handle errors. Don't assume success.
rationale: APIs fail. Network issues happen. Handle errors for good UX.
example_good: Check if status is 200. If not, show friendly error.
example_bad: Assume HTTP call succeeds and use response data directly

title: Use authentication for production agents
description: Production agents should require authentication. Use Authenticate with Microsoft for internal agents.
rationale: Auth identifies users, enables personalization, provides audit trails.
example_good: Set auth to Authenticate with Microsoft for internal HR bot
example_bad: No authentication for an agent accessing employee data

title: Version agents with solution deployment
description: Use Power Platform solutions to version and deploy. Never edit production directly.
rationale: Solutions provide version control and rollback. Direct edits are risky.
example_good: Dev → export solution → test → production
example_bad: Edit production agent directly

title: Limit SharePoint knowledge to specific sites
description: Add specific SharePoint sites with relevant content, not the entire tenant.
rationale: Broad knowledge increases response time and may include irrelevant content.
example_good: Add HR Policies SharePoint site for HR bot
example_bad: Add entire company SharePoint as knowledge

title: Use 5-10 trigger phrases per topic
description: Add varied trigger phrases including synonyms and common misspellings.
rationale: More variations improve topic matching accuracy.
example_good: Check order, order status, where is my order, track package
example_bad: Only one phrase: check order status

title: Log important events to Application Insights
description: Connect to Application Insights and log errors, escalations, important actions.
rationale: Logging enables monitoring and debugging. You can't improve what you can't measure.
example_good: Log escalations, API failures, unknown intents
example_bad: No logging, rely on user complaints

title: Use MCP servers for complex integrations
description: For complex integrations (CRM, ERP), use MCP servers instead of raw HTTP. MCP provides tooling and governance.
rationale: MCP abstracts complexity, provides updates, and integrates with governance.
example_good: Use Dataverse MCP to query records
example_bad: Build complex HTTP logic for Dataverse API

title: Don't expose sensitive data in responses
description: Never display full SSN, credit cards, passwords. Use masking.
rationale: Conversations may be logged or visible. Protect sensitive data.
example_good: Show Card ending in 4242
example_bad: Display full credit card number

title: Test in multiple channels before publishing
description: Test in all deployment channels. Behavior differs between Teams, web, mobile.
rationale: Channels have different capabilities and message limits.
example_good: Test in web, then Teams, then mobile before production
example_bad: Only test in web, deploy to Teams

title: Document your agent architecture
description: Create docs showing topic flow, integrations, dependencies, maintenance procedures.
rationale: Documentation enables handoff and troubleshooting.
example_good: README with architecture, integrations, common issues
example_bad: No documentation, all knowledge in one person's head

title: Review and update knowledge sources regularly
description: Schedule regular reviews. Remove outdated content, add new content.
rationale: Stale knowledge leads to wrong answers.
example_good: Monthly review: check policies, add new docs, remove old
example_bad: Set up knowledge once and never look at it again

title: Implement conversation timeout handling
description: Plan for users who abandon mid-flow. Check for incomplete sessions in Conversation Start.
rationale: Users get distracted. Handle timeouts gracefully.
example_good: Check for incomplete orders, offer to continue or start fresh
example_bad: Assume users always complete conversations
